title: TA_AH_Multi-agency partnerships and young people's experiences of schooling
abstractText:
This investigation focuses on multi-agency approaches and the experiences of young people. Current multi-agency policy encourages young people's participation at the level of service use and decision-making. Therefore, this investigation explores young people's perceptions of engagement and participation.

This research focuses on multi-agency approaches and experiences in the particular context of UK extended schools. Within this research, both professionals and young people are considered as key agents in constructing multi-agency experiences and outcomes. Attention is given to the extent to which multi-agency approaches affect young people's experiences as well as inter-professional dynamics.

This study runs from September 2007 to December 2008 and focuses on 10 extended school sites in the UK through a case study approach. A diverse range of participants is incorporated in order to gain insights into young people's experiences, perceptions and outcomes and to develop awareness of collaborative practices and processes emerging in multi-agency contexts. One-to-one interviews and group interviews will be conducted to include young people, senior strategic leaders, multi-agency co-ordinators and lead professionals, headteachers, frontline multi-agency professionals and teachers.
